subject: Communication
title: Seating Arrangements and Power Dynamics
description: A 60-second lesson on Seating Arrangements and Power Dynamics.

hook.text: King Arthur used a round table to eliminate hierarchy. The shape of the table shapes the conversation.

buildup.text: Rectangular tables create power positions (head vs. sides). Round tables distribute status more evenly.

discovery.text: Research shows people seated across from each other are more likely to compete; side-by-side, they cooperate.

twist.text: Sitting at the head of a table makes you 4x more likely to be perceived as the leader â€” even without a title.

climax.text: Therapists sit at angles, not across â€” reducing confrontation. Police interrogators sit directly across.

punchline.text: Where you sit tells people who you are before you speak.

quiz.question: What seating arrangement tends to promote cooperation?
options: Facing each other across a table
